key_points: Rep. Jerry Nadler incorrectly claimed Kyle Rittenhouse crossed state lines armed before the Kenosha shootings.
No evidence supports Rittenhouse transported the gun across state lines; it was stored in Kenosha.
Dominick Black, Rittenhouse's friend, testified he bought the AR-15 style gun for Rittenhouse in Wisconsin.
Rittenhouse was acquitted for the shootings during the 2020 Kenosha unrest, sparking varied reactions.
Nadler's tweet suggested Rittenhouse was seeking trouble while armed, linking this to crossing state lines.
Nadler's spokesperson clarified the tweet was about Rittenhouse crossing state lines, not necessarily armed.
Rittenhouse faced a misdemeanor charge for gun possession as a minor, which was dismissed.
The AR-15 was kept in a safe at Black's home in Kenosha and was only accessed by Rittenhouse during the unrest.
The misinformation in Nadler's tweet contributes to confusion surrounding the case's details.
The article concludes Nadler's claim is false based on trial testimony regarding the gun's location.
